title: Hyperkähler manifold
summary: In differential geometry, a hyperkähler manifold is a Riemannian manifold ( M , g ) {\displaystyle (M,g)} endowed with three integrable almost complex structures I , J , K {\displaystyle I,J,K} that are Kähler with respect to the Riemannian metric g {\displaystyle g} and satisfy the quaternionic relations I 2 = J 2 = K 2 = I J K = − 1 {\displaystyle I^{2}=J^{2}=K^{2}=IJK=-1} . In particular, it is a hypercomplex manifold. All hyperkähler manifolds are Ricci-flat and are thus Calabi–Yau manifolds.[lower-alpha 1]
